heroImage.alt: Visitors exploring interactive demo stands during Digitalidag at Linnaeus University.

highlights.text: Nationwide Digitalidag programming with unique sessions hosted by Linnaeus University.
Activities span both campuses and extend into community venues in Kalmar and Växjö.
Focus on cybersecurity, AI, digital transformation, and playful learning for all ages.

overview.text: Digitalidag is a nationwide theme day filled with digital activities, hands-on workshops, and discussions across Sweden.
Linnaeus University contributes with expert talks, interactive labs, and public events tailored for students, families, professionals, and local communities.
Sessions cover cybersecurity, AI, digital transformation, and playful learning at Universitetskajen in Kalmar, Växjö campus, Araby Park Arena, and Växjö Stadsbibliotek.

expectations.text: Panel discussion on cybersecurity (Kalmar · Hus Stella) — municipal leaders, industry experts, and LNU IT specialists discuss hacker attacks on workplaces, authorities, and private individuals. Speakers include Christoffer Carlsson Schött, Niklas Hörling, Louise Östlund, Henrik Ryttergard, Peter Bergehamn, and Pär Igevik. A recording is available on the event page.

Breakfast meeting “Konkurrenskraft genom digitalisering” (Kalmar Business Lab) — in collaboration with Smålandsnavet, researchers John Jeansson and Krister Bredmar show how organizations can strengthen competitiveness through digital transformation.
Experiment workshop on Generative AI (Växjö campus) — Jonas Svensson leads a hands-on exploration of AI tools, human–machine interaction, and the project Människa, maskin, samhälle.
“Lek och lär” play lab (Araby Park Arena, Växjö) — children discover digital creativity through playful stations that make technology easy to understand.

Public lecture on IoT & AI (Växjö Stadsbibliotek) — Jonas Nordqvist shares practical examples of how IoT, data-driven development, and AI drive innovation, together with Kronobergs Läns Tekniska Förening.

schedule.text: Universitetskajen, Kalmar — cybersecurity panel, business breakfast, and outreach activations.
Växjö campus — experiment workshops on Generative AI plus student-led demos.
Community venues — Araby Park Arena play lab and Växjö Stadsbibliotek public lecture the day before Digitalidag.

participation.text: Digitalidag is Sweden’s national initiative to strengthen digital participation and knowledge.
Linnaeus University contributes every year with a broad cross-campus programme for learners of all ages.
More information: Digitalidag at Linnaeus University · Digitalidag Sweden.
Read the latest update: https://lnu.se/mot-linneuniversitetet/aktuellt/nyheter/2024/digitalidag-2024/

images.alt: Students experimenting with VR headsets during Digitalidag in Växjö.
images.caption: Curious visitors testing immersive technology demos together.

images.alt: Panel speakers discussing cybersecurity strategies at Digitalidag.
images.caption: Regional leaders and LNU experts sharing insights on digital safety.

images.alt: Families gathered around a programming station during Digitalidag.
images.caption: Inclusive sessions welcome both students and families on campus.

heroImage.alt: Volvo CE logotype displayed during VERA Day in Braås.

highlights.text: Inspirational tech day for 5th-grade pupils focused on creativity and engineering thinking.
Hosted by Volvo CE in Braås together with participating Linnaeus University students.
Hands-on sessions exploring safety, innovation, VR demos, and introductory coding.
Encourages young girls to stay curious about technology and consider future engineering careers.

overview.text: VERA Day at Volvo is an initiative designed to inspire young girls to explore technology, innovation, and engineering.
Volvo CE in Braås welcomes two classes of 5th-grade pupils to learn how engineers think, create, and solve real-world problems.
Two students from Linnaeus University join the Volvo team on-site to help facilitate activities and answer questions.
The day aims to spark early interest in STEM by showing that technology is creative, meaningful, and accessible to everyone.

expectations.text: Innovation challenges such as brainstorming how technology can make traffic safer.
Group problem-solving where pupils present ideas to classmates and compare approaches.
VR demonstrations that let pupils experience engineering concepts virtually.
Introductory coding exercises that highlight logic, creativity, and digital creation.
Tech exploration stations showing how Volvo CE engineers design machinery, safety features, and future mobility.
Sharing session at the end of the day where pupils present their creative solutions.

schedule.text: Volvo CE, Braås — engineering facilities and activity rooms used for workshops, VR, and innovation sessions.

participation.text: VERA Day is arranged by Volvo CE to promote early interest in engineering among young pupils, especially girls.
Two Linnaeus University students assist on-site, supporting workshops and guiding discussions. For more information or photos, contact the organizing team.

images.alt: Volvo CE logotype prepared for VERA Day signage.
images.caption: Branding and onsite signage welcome pupils to VERA Day in Braås.

heroImage.alt: Educators listening to a keynote during Digitala kompetensdagen on Växjö campus.

highlights.text: Annual conference for educators and school leaders in Kronoberg County.
Focus on digital competence, new tools, pedagogical innovation, and digital transformation.
Co-arranged by AV-Media Region Kronoberg and Linnaeus University on Växjö campus.

overview.text: Digitala kompetensdagen is a full-day conference designed to strengthen digital competence among the region’s educators and school leaders.
Participants receive new ideas, tools, and knowledge while monitoring the latest developments in digital learning.
The 2025 edition takes place on 28 October at Linnaeus University in Växjö, arranged in collaboration with AV-Media Region Kronoberg.

expectations.text: Presentations and workshops on digital pedagogical tools and digital transformation in schools.
Classroom innovation sessions sharing new methods and best practices for digital learning.
Facilitated discussions about opportunities, challenges, and future-ready skills.

schedule.text: Växjö campus · Hus K hosts the plenary talks and main sessions.
Surrounding learning spaces on campus accommodate workshops and breakout discussions.

participation.text: Digitala kompetensdagen is jointly organized by AV-Media Region Kronoberg and Linnaeus University.
Programme updates and registration details will be published on the event webpage.
Visitor information, including travel tips and campus access, is available online.
Learn more: https://lnu.se/mot-linneuniversitetet/aktuellt/kalender/2025/digitala-kompetensdagen-2025/

images.alt: Participants networking between sessions at Digitala kompetensdagen.
images.caption: Regional educators and school leaders exchanging ideas on digital learning.

heroImage.alt: Children collaborating on Scratch projects during the programming course for kids.

highlights.text: Scratch programming course for children aged 10–12.
Delivered by TeMa Linné together with Kodcentrum.
Supported by Linnaeus University students plus new industry and community partners.
Offered in both Swedish and English to welcome all participants.

overview.text: During school holidays, TeMa Linné invites children aged 10–12 to an introductory Scratch course built on Kodcentrum’s learning material and led by skilled student instructors.
Successful sessions throughout 2023–2024 sparked new collaborations with local companies and community organizations, allowing the course to keep growing.

expectations.text: Hands-on Scratch programming sessions that build logic, creativity, and problem-solving skills.
Guided instruction from student leaders from the Department of Computer Science and Media Technology.
Inspirational visits and Q&As with developers from Sigma Technology AB and Softhouse.
Mixed-language teaching (Swedish and English) so every participant feels included.
Opportunities for children to explore campus and meet university student role models.

schedule.text: Course leaders: Shota Napetvaridze, Maria Ihrmark, and Floris van Der Staaij.
Industry partners: Sigma Technology AB and Softhouse.
Community collaborators: Araby Park Arena and Centrumskolan in Växjö.
Content provider: Kodcentrum, together with TeMa Linné’s student instructors.

participation.text: Collaborations with Araby Park Arena inspired deeper Scratch workshops and campus visits.
Next course opportunity is planned for the upcoming school break (Påsklovet).
Extra learning resources are available at Kodboken.se for children who want to keep coding at home.
Read more: https://lnu.se/mot-linneuniversitetet/aktuellt/nyheter/2024/lyckat-samarbete-pa-programmeringskurs-for-barn/

images.caption: Small-group coaching builds creativity before moving into the lab.

images.caption: Hands-on labs let every child present their own project.

details.text: Location: Outreach venues in Växjö & Kalmar

heroImage.alt: Linnaeus University mentors guiding PRAO pupils through Scratch activities.

highlights.text: Internship-style visit for pupils in grades 8–9 to explore programming and technology.
Small-group teaching sessions with hands-on activities in Scratch and Python.
Guided by students and staff from Linnaeus University.
Focus on understanding basic programming concepts, problem-solving, and digital thinking.
Offered twice per semester with a maximum of two pupils per week.

overview.text: PRAO Week (Praktisk arbetslivsorientering) gives pupils in grades 8–9 the chance to explore working life and gain insight into technology and programming at Linnaeus University.
During their visit, pupils take part in structured teaching sessions prepared by LNU students and staff, combining visual programming in Scratch with introductory Python coding.
The goal is to introduce fundamental concepts in computer science, build confidence in problem-solving, and show young learners what studying or working in the tech field can look like.
PRAO weeks are hosted twice per semester, with two pupils per week to ensure a personalized learning experience.

expectations.text: Scratch programming basics that build sequences and event-driven thinking.
Asking for input and storing responses inside Scratch variables.
Logical comparisons with integer values that drive decisions.
Using if–else statements to explore multiple outcomes.
Changing sprites and costumes based on conditions to visualize logic.
Understanding how the structure of code leads to the on-screen behavior pupils see.
Guided transition from Scratch concepts to introductory Python.
Discussing the difference between strings and integers when working with data.
Taking user input and storing it in Python variables.
Printing and combining text with numeric values inside Python programs.
Writing simple conditional statements in Python using if/else.
Reading and interpreting basic error messages together with mentors.
Introduction to debugging techniques that help pupils fix mistakes.
Every session starts with a short concept presentation followed by hands-on practice.

schedule.text: Linnaeus University, Växjö campus — teaching labs and learning environments used for introductory programming workshops.

participation.text: PRAO Week is intended for pupils in grades 8–9 as part of their practical workplace orientation period.
Participation is arranged together with schools, and each PRAO period hosts two pupils for tailored instruction.

images.alt: Two pupils presenting a Scratch project while mentors listen.
images.caption: Small-group Scratch sessions make it easy to ask questions throughout PRAO week.

images.alt: Students collaborating on laptops during an introductory Python exercise.
images.caption: Python practice shows how variables, input, and conditionals work in real time.

heroImage.alt: Students meeting company representatives during Karriärdag Teknik at Växjö campus.

highlights.text: Full day of networking between companies, organisations, and students within construction, IT, and technology.
Large career fair with exhibitors spread across multiple campus buildings.
Speed-dating sessions for internships, thesis projects, and job opportunities.
Open lectures from industry partners, startups, and university staff.
Programme streams tailored for construction, technology, and IT students.

overview.text: Karriärdag Teknik/Byggardagen is Linnaeus University’s annual career event connecting students with companies in the technology, IT, and construction sectors.
The event helps students build professional networks, explore internships, find thesis partners, and map future career paths.
Visitors can meet employers at the fair, attend lectures, join speed-dating sessions, and take part in activities across Växjö campus.

expectations.text: Career fair with regional and national exhibitors placed across Hus M, K, N, and nearby buildings.
Speed-dating sessions where students book short meetings for internships, thesis projects, and jobs.
Guest lectures by Volvo, Sigma Industry South, Skanska, Softwerk, and other partners.
Startup sessions hosted by LNU Innovation and Växjö Linnaeus Science Park about the journey from idea to company.
Student-focused talks covering AI in studies, consulting vs employment, and career planning.
Meme competition with prizes handed out in Glasgallerian plus lunch wraps for registered participants.

schedule.text: Växjö campus — Hus M, Hus K, Hus N, and surrounding buildings hosting fairs and lectures.
Glasgallerian — prize ceremony for the Meme competition.

participation.text: Open to students in construction, data/IT, engineering, and related programmes.
Resources include exhibitor lists (PDF), building maps, speed-dating registration, exhibitor info, and travel guidance between Kalmar ↔ Växjö.
Questions: samverkan.ftk@lnu.se.
Official event page: https://lnu.se/mot-linneuniversitetet/aktuellt/kalender/2025/konferenser/karriardag-teknikbyggardagen-2025/

images.alt: Recruiters and students networking beside the Karriärdag Teknik stands.
images.caption: Växjö campus fair floor buzzing with conversations between visitors and companies.

name: Talk about student life at LNU

heroImage.alt: Current Linnaeus University students speaking with visitors during the student life talk.

details.text: Location: Växjö campus · Karriärdag Teknik fair area

highlights.text: Informal Q&A with current Linnaeus University students during Career Day in Technology.
Chance for high school visitors to ask about programmes, campus life, and the transition to university.
Real stories about courses, housing, student associations, and everyday life on campus.

overview.text: The Student Life Information Session is a short, conversational event held during Karriärdag Teknik.
High school students visiting the career fair meet current LNU students from multiple programmes for honest discussions about studies.
Hosts share experiences of courses, campus environment, housing, student associations, and everyday life to help visitors picture their future.

expectations.text: Ask questions directly to current university students about programmes and workload.
Hear tips about teaching formats, study balance, and transitioning from high school to university.
Learn about housing, campus services, student associations, and social life.
Explore next steps such as visiting Open House events or applying to programmes.

schedule.text: Växjö campus — hosted in a presentation room or fair area during Karriärdag Teknik.

participation.text: Open to high school groups attending Career Day in Technology.
Designed to build confidence and clarity about studying at Linnaeus University.
For more information, contact the Career Day organising team.

details.text: Location: Outreach venues in Växjö & Kalmar

heroImage.alt: Student ambassadors greeting visitors at Linnaeus University Open House.

highlights.text: Recruit future students through inspirational sessions and fair activities.
Offer guided tours, open labs, or sample lectures that showcase your programme.
Plan for both morning and afternoon timeslots to meet visiting school groups.

overview.text: Open House is a perfect opportunity to recruit more students to your programme. During the events, you can increase visibility by running inspirational sessions and by taking part as an exhibitor at the fair. You can also register a guided tour or another activity of your choice—such as a visit to your programme’s facilities, an open lab, or a sample lecture.

Open House is one of Linnaeus University’s largest recruitment initiatives of the academic year, and in 2025 nearly 2 500 people visited across both the Växjö and Kalmar campuses. Most visitors come from upper secondary schools in Småland and Blekinge, but we also welcome many from further afield across Sweden.

Since 2025, Open House has been a joint event for both campuses, with the project group aiming to present a similar range of activities for visitors regardless of whether they choose to attend in Växjö or in Kalmar.

expectations.text: The inspirational sessions give you the opportunity to explain why students should choose your programme. They may be led by the programme coordinator, a study counsellor, or current students. We recommend involving students in some way so they can describe everyday life as a student. Each session lasts 20 minutes, during which you present your programme and host a Q&A.

The fair is an opportunity to have in-depth conversations with prospective students. It's also a great way to make your programme visible and generate interest among visitors who may not attend your specific inspiration session. We recommend planning an activity at your stand to make it easier to attract visitors.

Guided tours and activities offer a chance to showcase a specific learning environment or highlight an aspect of your programme. This could include opening up a lab, a tour of a studio, a concert with students, or a hands-on activity. Feel free to come up with your own ideas!

schedule.text: Campus Växjö — Thursday 26 February at 9 am–2 pm
Campus Kalmar — Wednesday 4 March at 9 am–2 pm
Each inspirational session should be offered at least once in the morning and once in the afternoon to accommodate visiting schools.

participation.text: Registration for participation at Open House 2026 is open from 1 September and closes on 31 October.
Register here.
Any questions? Contact the project group for Open House at oppethus@lnu.se.
See information published for external visitors.

images.alt: Student ambassador speaking with visitors at the Open House fair stand.
images.caption: Inspiration stand conversations with prospective students.

images.alt: Student demonstrating a project during Open House.
images.caption: Hands-on demos that showcase programme highlights.

images.alt: Overview of the Open House fair floor with visitors exploring exhibits.
images.caption: Fair floor buzzing with activity throughout the day.

heroImage.alt: Visitors exploring exhibits and speaking to student ambassadors at Öppet hus in Kalmar.

highlights.text: Meet university staff, students, and study counsellors on Kalmar campus.
Explore programmes through inspirational sessions, info talks, and hands-on activities.
Fair area open all day with opportunities to ask about student life, housing, and admissions.
Campus-wide tours and programme showcases running throughout the event.

overview.text: On 4 March 2026, Linnaeus University invites prospective students to Kalmar campus for Öppet hus to inspire and inform future applicants.
Visitors can join talks, explore learning environments, meet current students, and get answers about programmes, applications, and student life.
The fair runs 09.00–14.00 with inspirational sessions, general info talks, tours, and activities scheduled across campus.

expectations.text: Inspirational programme sessions led by teachers, students, and staff.
General information sessions about studying at LNU, admissions, and campus services.
Guided campus tours showcasing Kalmar’s labs, learning spaces, and programme facilities.
Fair area where visitors meet academic departments and university services.
Opportunities to talk with current students about their experiences in Kalmar.

schedule.text: Kalmar campus — university fair, presentation rooms, and guided tour starting points.
Faculty buildings and labs hosting activities and programme showcases.

participation.text: More information and updates will be published on the official event page.
Learn more: https://lnu.se/mot-linneuniversitetet/aktuellt/kalender/2026/oppet-hus-kalmar/

details.text: Languages: Swedish (information in English available · women only)

heroImage.alt: Participants collaborating during an IGEday workshop at Volvo CE.

highlights.text: National initiative introducing girls and non-binary youth to life as an engineer.
Participants aged 13–19 get hands-on experiences at real engineering workplaces across Sweden.
Company participation is open to organizations with at least one woman engineer.
Supported and organized by the Womengineer Foundation.
Focus on empowering young people to explore engineering and choose their future with confidence.

overview.text: IGEday is a nationwide event where girls and non-binary individuals aged 13–19 explore what it's like to work as an engineer while companies across Sweden host interactive sessions, workshops, and hands-on activities.
The next IGEday takes place on March 20, 2026, with participant registration opening on January 7.
The initiative inspires young people to view engineering as an exciting, accessible career path, with recurring hosts such as Siemens Energy, E.ON, and Tetra Pak.

expectations.text: Guided tours of engineering workplaces that showcase labs, control rooms, and project spaces.
Hands-on problem-solving sessions where participants build prototypes, test ideas, and collaborate with engineers.
Talks from engineers and role models sharing study paths, daily work, and tips for choosing programmes.
Group challenges, teamwork activities, and Q&A opportunities about studies and career paths.
Teachers, mentors, and student counsellors are welcome to accompany groups and support the experience.
Inspirational stories from women engineers and young participants highlighting different futures within technology.

schedule.text: Company participation is open to any organization with at least one woman engineer, and registration for IGEday 2026 hosts closes on November 30.
Participant registration opens on January 7, with the list of participating companies updated continuously at https://igeday.com so applicants can choose their preferred workplace.
On March 20, 2026, hosts across Sweden run morning or full-day sessions, from factory tours to innovation workshops.

participation.text: Anyone aged 13–19 who identifies as a girl or non-binary can sign up individually or as part of a school group.
Hosts need at least one woman engineer and can design tours, workshops, or lab sessions that reflect their workplace and teams.

Quotes from previous participants include "The best part was hearing what life as an engineer is like.", "The most fun part was solving tasks together.", and "I got to see what my future workplace might look like!"

IGEday is organized by the Womengineer Foundation, whose goal is for Sweden to graduate as many female engineers as male engineers by 2030 while supporting UN Sustainable Development Goals 4, 5, and 10.
The initiative is made possible through partners, schools, companies, and volunteers across Sweden who coordinate logistics and mentoring.
More information, FAQs, and inspiration from previous years are available on the official website: https://igeday.com.

images.alt: Participant testing VR equipment during IGEday.
images.caption: Immersive demos make engineering concepts easier to understand.

images.alt: Linnaeus University students guiding IGEday visitors.
images.caption: Student mentors from LNU help pupils navigate each activity.

heroImage.alt: Families exploring hands-on science experiments during Science Linné.

highlights.text: Annual science and technology festival attracting over 1,000 visitors.
Hands-on experiments, demonstrations, and challenges for students and the public.
Exhibitors from Linnaeus University and regional tech companies.
Activities across LEGO engineering, robotics, biology, VR, and structural engineering.
Designed to spark curiosity for technology, natural sciences, and mathematics.

overview.text: Science City transforms the Växjö campus into a vibrant environment filled with technology, science, and excitement.
The latest edition drew more than 1,000 visitors who explored interactive stations, live demonstrations, and creative challenges.
Exhibitors included LNU departments and regional companies showing everything from robotics to environmental science.

expectations.text: Full-scale LEGO Volvo V70 exhibited by David Gustafsson, winner of LEGO Masters Sverige.
Engineering challenges: build-a-catapult stations, 3D virtual airplanes, and remote-controlled car testing.
Creative making: turning wooden apples, building structures, and testing math magic tricks.
Science exploration: observing algae through microscopes and tasting algae smoothies.
Technology showcases: industrial robots, student-built dance mats, and VR experiences of student life.
“Starkast vinner!” bridge-building competition with wooden bridges holding over 40 kg.
Morning entry for pre-booked grade 5–9 groups; afternoon open to upper-secondary students and the public.

schedule.text: Organized by Linnaeus University with Epic, sponsored by Teknikcollege and Växjö kommun.
Powered by university staff, student volunteers, and regional tech companies.
Project leaders Laure Fournier and Katrin Lindwall highlight the importance of inspiring young people.

keyLocations.text: Växjö campus — multiple buildings and open areas hosting exhibition booths, workshops, and demonstrations.

participation.text: More information and photos: https://lnu.se/mot-linneuniversitetet/aktuellt/nyheter/2023/dricka-alger-bygga-broar-och-svarva-applen--science-city-gav-manga-smakprov-for-den-teknikintresserade/

images.caption: Robotics stations invite curious minds to test automation and coding.

images.alt: Participants experimenting with engineering challenges inside the expo hall.
images.caption: Interactive build stations encourage teamwork and creative problem solving.

images.caption: VR demos showcase future study environments and student projects.

highlights.text: Scratch programming course for children aged 10–12.
Delivered by TeMa Linné together with Kodcentrum.
Supported by Linnaeus University students plus new industry and community partners.
Offered in both Swedish and English to welcome all participants.

overview.text: During school holidays, TeMa Linné invites children aged 10–12 to an introductory Scratch course built on Kodcentrum’s learning material and led by skilled student instructors.
Successful sessions throughout 2023–2024 sparked new collaborations with local companies and community organizations, allowing the course to keep growing.

expectations.text: Hands-on Scratch programming sessions that build logic, creativity, and problem-solving skills.
Guided instruction from student leaders from the Department of Computer Science and Media Technology.
Inspirational visits and Q&As with developers from Sigma Technology AB and Softhouse.
Mixed-language teaching (Swedish and English) so every participant feels included.
Opportunities for children to explore campus and meet university student role models.

schedule.text: Course leaders: Shota Napetvaridze, Maria Ihrmark, and Floris van Der Staaij.
Industry partners: Sigma Technology AB and Softhouse.
Community collaborators: Araby Park Arena and Centrumskolan in Växjö.
Content provider: Kodcentrum, together with TeMa Linné’s student instructors.

participation.text: Collaborations with Araby Park Arena inspired deeper Scratch workshops and campus visits.
Next course opportunity is planned for the upcoming school break (Påsklovet).
Extra learning resources are available at Kodboken.se for children who want to keep coding at home.
Read more: https://lnu.se/mot-linneuniversitetet/aktuellt/nyheter/2024/lyckat-samarbete-pa-programmeringskurs-for-barn/

images.alt: Student mentors guiding children as they plan Scratch stories on paper.
images.caption: Small-group coaching builds creativity before moving into the lab.

images.alt: Participant sharing a Scratch project on a laptop with the group.
images.caption: Hands-on labs let every child present their own project.

images.alt: Kids collaborating around computers during the programming course.
images.caption: TeMa Linné tutors support each participant throughout the session.
